Starting 6 Jan to 10 January 2022 the whole of the Northern Territory is in a lockout.  From 13 Jan to 20 Jan lockout was localized to NT areas of Amoonguna, Yuendumu and Yuelamu.  While no restrictions are in place for business closures, businesses and organisations are obligated to ensure employees, customers, visitors and participants are fully vaccinated. Unvaccinated people may access essential services only including supermarkets, hospitals or to get takeaway food.    During a lockout, fully vaccinated residents can live normally within a lockout area. Unvaccinated people aged 16 years and over, including people whoâve received only their first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine, must stay at home during a lockout period and are only permitted to leave for essential reasons.     You canât travel more than 30km from your home when leaving for 1 of the 3 reasons. If you need to go to the hospital and itâs more than 30km from your home, thatâs permitted.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220106095319/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114131655/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/information-about-face-masks

From 17 January 2022 Galiwin'ku will be in lockdown for 7 days. There are additional lockouts in place.      The lockdown applies to everyone, whether or not they are vaccinated. Essential workers who are fully vaccinated can continue to go to work.    People can only leave home to:    -receive medical treatment, including COVID testing or vaccination  -obtain essential goods and services, like groceries, power tokens and medications â only one household member once per day  -do 1 hour of outdoor exercise per day, with one other person or people from your household â masks are required while exercising  -provide care and support to a family member or person who cannot support themselves, or in case of an emergency    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121170948/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114131655/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/information-about-face-masks

Only essential workers who are fully vaccinated can continue to go to work. There are lockdowns in place for Ampilatwatja, Milikapiti, Galiwinâku, Gunyangara, Wurrumiyanga and all land known as the Utopia Homelands. Currently the longest lockdown is for Elcho Island including Galiwinâku and the Wessel Islands including Martjanba, until 31 January 2022. However lockdowns and lockouts continue to be extended or put in place.     During a lockdown, residents must stay at home and are only permitted to leave for the following four reasons:    - Medical treatment, including COVID testing and vaccination  - For essential goods and services, like groceries, medications or power tokens. Only one household member should visit the store, once per day  - For one hour of outdoor exercise a day within 5 km from your home with one other person or people from your house  - To provide care and support to a family member or person who cannot support themselves, or in the case of an emergency including escaping harm from domestic/family violence .  - Essential workers who are fully vaccinated can continue to go to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

No new policy. Although lockouts are in place in NT, public events are able to be held but not attended by unvaccinated people. You need to show proof of vaccination when visiting certain venues. Following the end of lockdowns (14 Dec) events can operate but typically with restrictions - ex. only vaccinated staff and patrons, and those with a medical exemption, will be allowed to enter:   - indoor entertainment venues such as nightclubs, live music venues, karaoke bars, concerts, theatres or cinemas and casinos  - outdoor entertainment activities such as sporting stadiums or theme parks  - festivals â either indoor or outdoor â such as musical, folk or arts festivals  - activities â either indoor or outdoor â such as convention centres and showgrounds      https://web.archive.org/web/20220114131655/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/information-about-face-masks  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106095740/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/qld

Lockdowns and lockouts in the NT areas. Although regulations vary, all interstate travel is restricted to some degree. All travelers to the Northern Territory must complete a border entry form. Entry is prohibited from current hotspots or public exposure sites without a prior approved exemption attached to your border entry form. The government of Western Australia (WA) has enacted a controlled interstate border arrangement. All travelers must register online before traveling to Western Australia. The areas where travelers have spent time prior to arriving in Western Australia determine conditions of their entry and any possible quarantine, vaccination, and/or COVID-19 testing requirements. Currently all areas of AUS are considered an extreme risk. You are not permitted to enter without an approval through G2G Pass (external link). Exemptions are restricted to Commonwealth, State and specialist functions only; If permitted entry, you will be directed to undertake 14 days hotel quarantine at a Government approved quarantine facility at your own expense.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220107081429/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220114141037/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106102244/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.     All inbound passengers must also provide proof of vaccination status before arrival through the Australia Travel Declaration, unless they are a child under the age of 12 years and 3 months. It is important to note that previous infection with COVID-19 is not considered a medical contraindication for COVID-19 vaccination.    Passengers providing a medical certificate to provide this proof must ensure that the medical certificate is in English and includes the following information:    -their name (this must match their travel identification documents)  -date of medical consultation and details of their medical practitioner  -details that clearly outline that they have a medical condition that means they cannot receive a COVID-19 vaccination (vaccination is contraindicated).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116005735/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106102244/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Face masks are mandatory in all indoor settings across the Northern Territory. This includes pubs, clubs, restaurants, shopping centres, hairdressers, workplaces, public transport, taxi cabs, ride share and indoor boat cruises.    It is also recommended you wear a mask outdoors if you can't maintain a physical distance of 1.5 metres.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220108124308/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/face-masks/nt

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111557/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111557/https://www.agedcarequality.gov.au/sites/default/files/media/letter-commissioner-residential-approved-providers-being-prepared-for-covid-19-outbreak-22-december-2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

No new policy. Continued from 13 September 2021, everyone in Australia aged 12 years and over is eligible for a free COVID-19 vaccination.     It appears that starting on the 8th of November people over 18 will be eligible for a booster shot (6 months after their completion of the second dosis).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211201170746/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-your-vaccination/booster-doses    https://web.archive.org/web/20210916120513/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004191741/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/who-can-get-vaccinated

No new policy. Continuing the COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in Australia. Vaccination providers cannot charge you for the COVID-19 vaccine or your appointments to receive the vaccine.    If your vaccination provider charges for any costs associated with the administration of the COVID-19 vaccination (including booking fees), you should:    contact us by emailing provider.benefits.integrity@health.gov.au,  or call the Provider Benefits Integrity Hotline on 1800 314 808 (9am to 5pm AEST weekdays).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423124712/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19

No changes. In-person learning will restart on January 3, 2022 for Bruneian students.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129

In-person learning have restarted on January 3, 2022 for Bruneian students, in phases.    "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

Phase 2 of reintroducing in-person learning for Bruneian students has commenced on January 17, 2022.    Originally,  "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the frst Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    â    "Toddlers aged 3 to 4 can head back to kindergartens from January 17, the education minister said Wednesday.    Joining the COVID-19 news conference, Dato Hj Hamzah Hj Sulaiman said in-person lessons will be allowed for preschoolers five times a week, but attendance at kindergartens is capped at 30 percent.    To ensure the safety of preschoolers who are not authorised to receive the vaccine against COVID, only kindergartens that meet health requirements can reopen.    Kindergarten pupils will also be required to wear face masks and undergo antigen rapid tests once a week, with only those producing negative results permitted to attend in-person classes.    The minister said parents and guardians of the children must be fully jabbed and show proof of vaccination.    Double-vaccinated Year 7-9 pupils will also return to classrooms next week after a five-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, joining Year 10-13 students who were the first group to resume face-to-face classes earlier this month."    "Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

No change.    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:         Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.      All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)        Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)       Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41

No change.    "Public venues can increase capacity to 75%  As Brunei moves into the early endemic phase, the government also announced further easing of restrictions that will come into effect on December 15, 2021 and last until January 14, 2022.   During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place.   From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:         Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.      All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)        Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)       Government offices and service counters.     Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people  â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No change.    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived in Malay, at https://archive.vn/vfs6b (see point 2 under SOP Pembukaan Sekolah Memandu dan Pengangkutan Awam)

No change.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    However, night-time curfews are still in force, with the curfew remaining from 10pm to 4am.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the original Operasi Pulih, published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Peralihan, published on 10 Nov, archived at https://archive.vn/gwb8w  See the Scoop's report on the early endemic phase, published on 12 Dec, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No change.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    However, night-time curfews are still in force and extended to 14th February, with the curfew remaining but shortened to 12 to 4am from 15 January. Up to this date, Brunei's night-time curfews remain from 10pm to 4am. No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising of other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 07 Jan, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/Vu5eF  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Brunei backtracks on plans to lift travel curbs over Omicron concerns", archived at https://archive.vn/8lobr

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 03 Jan (https://archive.vn/jj3dT) and 05 Jan (https://archive.vn/6vn1d).    There were missing updates on 31 Dec; 01-02 Jan, 04 Jan, and 06-08 Jan.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 07 Jan,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/Vu5eF  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/FVmPV  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 07 Jan,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/Vu5eF  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm-BIBP (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran); Pfizer-BioNTech (tozinameran)    No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

Primary and secondary schools, vocational schools, colleges and universities, and private kindergartens within the Binhai New Area of Tianjin will suspend all educational and teaching activities. https://archive.vn/DKWuh
In Xi'an, shopping malls, supermarkets, and stores along the street have resumed business since Jan.24th.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-271.0-271.33

On January 12, Tianjin demanded the closure of general public places, the suspension of the opening of various religious places, and the suspension of collective religious activities. https://archive.vn/nyKzv
In Xi'an, public events can be hold but it is need to limit the number of participants to 50.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-309.15-309.30

On January 12, Tianjin issued the "Proposal for Epidemic Prevention and Control in Rural Areas of the City", which clearly stated that the holding of wedding ceremonies, brief funerals, and banquets would be suspended, and gathering activities such as village meetings and literary and art gatherings would be suspended. https://archive.vn/yoN5k

On January 23, 2022, Beijing designated Fengtai District as a prevention zone, and fengtai district was required to strengthen various epidemic prevention and control measures and suspend gathering activities.    See website: https://archive.vn/Q3pUA    See website: https://archive.vn/Q3pUA

It is recommended that no more than 10 people participate family dinner parties. It is recommended to delay wedding ceremony and simplify funerals and no banquets in XI'an.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-319.2-323.76
On 23 January, 2022, the full load ratio of rail transit and ground bus is adjusted to 75% in Beijing Fengtai District.     See website: https://archive.vn/Q3pUA

In Xi'an, buses, taxis, online car-hailing, subways, bus lines and other means of transportation have resumed operations in an all-round way, and drivers and passengers need to take personal protection since Jan.24th.   On 23 January, 2022, the full load ratio of rail transit and ground bus is adjusted to 75% in Beijing Fengtai District.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF  https://archive.vn/Q3pUA

From January 24, 2022, Xi'an City will be reduced to a low-risk area. However, Changan Area is still closed and one family member can come out every two days for shopping.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-171.0-183.12

As for Xi'an, people in low-risk areas outside the city can return with a 48-hour negative nucleic acid test certificate, a communication big data itinerary card, and Xi'an "One Code Pass" with a green code.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-213.13-221.37
On 23 January, 2022, the elderly care institutions in Beijing Fengtai District are closed.     See website: https://archive.vn/Q3pUA

In-person instruction for all educational institutions, including public and private K-12 schools, colleges, and universities and those staff not engaged in distance learning or not performing critical functions is authorized; provided the following are implemented:        Adherence to DPHSS Guidance Memorandum 2021-02 (Minimum Requirements for In-Class Operations of K-12 Schools and Institutions of Higher Education) and DPHSS Guidance Memorandum 2021-09 (Additional Guidance Relative to Adopting 3 Feet Social Distancing for In-Class Operations for K-12 Schools) and any additional requirements as DPHSS deems necessary.      Distance learning by schools and its supporting activities is authorized, which include curb-side pick-up, delivery of materials and documents, and teachers utilizing their classrooms to conduct virtual classes.      In-person instruction guidelines and protocols are approved for the re-opening of schools.  https://archive.fo/GwfOk

As part of Guamâs ongoing effort to contain the spread of COVID-19, individuals entering Guam by air or sea shall be subject to a 10-day quarantine, except as provided herein. Individuals who are fully vaccinated may be exempt from quarantine. Individuals are considered fully vaccinated 2 weeks after their second dose in a 2-dose series, or 2 weeks after a single-dose vaccine. Passengers who present a negative COVID-19 viral test may be exempt from quarantine. This guidance does not apply to individuals identified as close contacts to persons with COVID-19. Arriving passengers (air or sea) with direct flight/voyage into Guam that originate from a country with No Reported Cases are not required to have a COVID-19 test and are not required to quarantine  https://archive.fo/178N4

Face masks are worn at all times by customers (and employees), except when actively eating and drinking;  Outdoor, non-contact, recreational activities, such as golf, tennis, shooting, scuba diving is authorized; provided, the following are implemented:      Social distancing of not less than 6 feet is maintained;      Face mask is worn whenever possible;  https://archive.fo/GwfOk

Shortening the interval for when eligible people can receive a booster dose, from 6 months to 5 months after completing their Pfizer-BioNTech primary series. This means that eligible people can receive an mRNA booster dose 5 months after completing their Pfizer-BioNTech primary series. The booster dose interval recommendations for people who received their Johnson & Johnson/Janssen (2 months) or Moderna (6 months) have not changed.  Expanding the COVID-19 boosters to adolescents ages 12 to 15 years old. At this time, only the Pfizer-BioNTech booster vaccine is authorized and recommended for adolescents aged 12 to 15 years old.  Authorizing a third primary series dose for certain immunocompromised children aged 5 to 11 years old. The Government today announced it will tighten social distancing measures from January 7 for a period of 14 days, including the cessation of mass events and dine-in services at catering businesses from 6pm to 4.59am.  Except for clubhouses and hotels or guesthouses, all scheduled premises regulated under Hong Kong Laws Cap 599F such as amusement game centres, bathhouses, fitness centres, places of amusement and party rooms must suspend operation. Bars or pubs will be closed.  Most of the leisure and cultural venues or facilities under the Leisure & Cultural Services Department will also be temporarily closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220119142858/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2022/01/20220105/20220105_164244_810.html?type=category&name=covid19&tl=t

Chief Executive Carrie Lam today said a higher COVID-19 jab rate would enable the Government to allow businesses to operate under a vaccine bubble and announced that social distancing rules will be extended until February 3.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220119145923/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2022/01/20220114/20220114_192425_954.html?type=category&name=covid19&tl=t

Social distancing measures will be tightened to the most stringent level as seen during the third and fourth waves of the epidemic, with a view to reducing public traffic, social functions and crowd gatherings to the greatest extent.  The prohibition on group gatherings of more than four people in public places will continue during the period.  Regarding catering business, during daytime services, the maximum number of customers per table for catering premises under Types B, C and D modes of operation will be reduced to two, four and six, whereas the maximum number of customers per premises and per banquet will remain unchanged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220119142858/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2022/01/20220105/20220105_164244_810.html?type=category&name=covid19&tl=t

Despite increasing cases, schools continue to remain open.  Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.  Schools have also resumed all club activities, events, and excursions; however strict infection control measures must be followed.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)  https://archive.fo/PdDnL

As a result of high case counts, the prefectures, Okinawa, Hiroshima, and Yamaguchi will implement priority countermeasures beginning January 9, 2022 (until 31st). These measures include closing restaurants and retail from 8/9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol. Upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees.  From January 11, 2022 in Tokyo (until 31st), restaurants certified by the local government may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 8 people per table. Vaccination certificate app should be used on groups with more than 5 people. For stores not certified by the city, they will limit customers to 4 people per group and close by 9PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220108010037/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012419/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220107/k10013420601000.html (gatherings in Okinawa, Hiroshima, Yamaguchi)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220105/k10013416701000.html (stores in Okinawa, Hiroshima, Yamaguchi)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012952/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220107/k10013419911000.html (stores in Tokyo)

Okinawa, Hiroshima, and Yamaguchi begin priority countermeasures beginning January 9, 2022 (until 31st).  Measures require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. In-restaurant dining is restricted for 4 per table of those in the same household for 2 hours maximum. Restaurants are also to operate at reduce capacity. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  Upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117162030/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115061522/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429151000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220113152356/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/220112taishohoshin_1.pdf

Tokyo begin restrictions in response to the omicron variant on January 11 and to continue until the 31st.  Measures require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. Restaurants may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 4 people per table. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  Upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173206/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020813.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173135/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html

On January 21st, 2022, priority measures come into effect for 13 of the following additonal prefectures (or metropolitans) until February 13th:  Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Niigata, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Kagawa, Nagasaki, Kumamoto, Miyazaki.  Priority measures already in effect in Okinawa, Yamaguchi, and Hiroshima will continue until at least January 31st.    No change to previous policy as events continue to be held with restrictions of capacity.  In Tokyo and Okinawa, upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123213135/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220120163925/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220119/k10013438191000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123215541/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0112eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173206/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020813.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173135/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html

No change to previous policy. Due to the omicron variant, all international travel controls are to continue after December 31st and into the new year.  Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa and leisure travel from all countries. Limited Visas are being processed and all incoming flights into the country are restricted to only 3,500 people in total per day.   Japan will also be extending the quarantine period at accommodation facilities for a number of additional countries.    https://archive.fo/fMpQs  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152325/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211203/k10013374241000.html  https://archive.fo/dhNu9  https://archive.fo/5nIhA

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://archive.fo/HTePO

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://archive.fo/HTePO

No change to previous policy.  Tokyo, Osaka, Okinawa, Fukuoka continues to offer free asymptomatic PCR testing at public and private facilities to all residents of the prefecture.  Tokyo will continue to offer free PCR testing to all individuals until January 31, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117175016/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220108/k10013421271000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://archive.fo/ZpbXV (Osaka & Tokyo)  https://archive.fo/v9SBG (Fukuoka)  https://archive.fo/JyBLE (Tokyo evidence)  https://archive.fo/7Tqmf (Tokyo evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013217/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220104/k10013414281000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)

Tokyo will continue to offer free PCR testing to all individuals until January 31, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117175016/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220108/k10013421271000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://archive.fo/ZpbXV (Osaka & Tokyo)  https://archive.fo/v9SBG (Fukuoka)  https://archive.fo/JyBLE (Tokyo evidence)  https://archive.fo/7Tqmf (Tokyo evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013217/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220104/k10013414281000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)

While PCR tests continue to be made available to all, at least until the end of January in Tokyo, Nagoya city is beginning to report signs that chemical reagents are limited and testing requires increasing wait for renewed supplies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054458/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220124/k10013447611000.html

In Tokyo, of the 25 people tested positive for the omicron strain, 11 had no history of travel and were community-acquired infections. Tokyo is expecting rapid increase in omicron cases as a result of the year-end holidays.    https://archive.fo/OldDN

While Tokyo and Osaka has increase resources for contact tracing, due to rapidly rising cases, Naha has announced effective January 4th, close contact tracing will temporarily be focused on high risk settings such as medical institutions and elderly or welfare facilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116210406/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1449967.html

In Okinawa and Hiroshima prefectures, with rising cases and insufficient personnel, standard contact tracing have also been suspended and contact tracing efforts have instead been focused on infections within hospitals, long-term care, and clusters within high risk groups.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116210406/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1449967.html

In Tokyo, Fukuoka prefecture, and Sapporo, due to significant increase in cases, resources for close contact tracing have also begun prioritizing those in high risk institutions such as medical centres and long term care homes. This is in addition to limited contact tracing in Okinawa and Hiroshima.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220120/k10013439931000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221613/https://www.pref.fukuoka.lg.jp/contents/jyuutenka.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/sapporo-news/20220120/7000042505.html

No change to previous policy. Osaka and Nagoya have also been reported to reduce capacity for comprehensive contact tracing in an effort to prioritize cases in high risk institutions. This comes in addition to overwhelmed contact tracing efforts in Tokyo, Fukuoka, Sapporo, Okinawa, and Hiroshima.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054301/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220126/k10013450041000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054458/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220124/k10013447611000.html (Nagoya)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220120/k10013439931000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221613/https://www.pref.fukuoka.lg.jp/contents/jyuutenka.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/sapporo-news/20220120/7000042505.html

Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://archive.fo/yw3cF (Japan emergency measures)

Due to significant spread of the omicron variant, as of January 9, other regions such as Chiba city, Hiroshima and Yamaguchi prefectures have all begun administering early third dose vaccinations for the elderly population, ahead of the original February national timeline.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117182045/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220111/k10013424521000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117182216/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220109/k10013422531000.html

On January 13, the government announces the shortening of interval for 3rd doses in the general population to 7 months. Previously for the general public, this period was 8 months. For medical personnel and the elderly population, the interval was previously shortened to 6 months.    Vaccination for children aged 5 to 11 years in Japan is expected to be approved on January 20th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117181752/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429491000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117182101/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429151000.html

On January 21st, 2022, vaccination for children age 5-11 has been approved for the Pfizer vaccine in Japan. The government has begun having discussions with local governments to add children 5-11 to the target of large-scale mass inoculation led by individual prefectures starting from February 1st, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123213206/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220121/k10013442001000.html

On January 28 2022, reservations for third dose vaccinations begin open for booking at mass vaccination sites operated by the Self-Defense Forces from the federal government. Booster dose vaccinations are set to begin on January 31st 2022.  The target of large-scale vaccination by the Self-Defense Forces is those who are 18 years of age or older and have a third vaccination ticket, beginning with the elderly population. Those who have not been vaccinated for more than 6 months since the second vaccination will not be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128201721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220126/k10013451691000.html

No change to previous policy. The government now allows visitations at long-term care homes restricted to visitors who have been fully vaccinated with two doses of the COVID-19 vaccination or have had a negative PCR test prior to the visitation.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of December 27, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023257/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360411000.html  https://archive.fo/d3uUA  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213153423/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html

As of January 9, other regions such as Chiba city, Hiroshima and Yamaguchi prefectures have all begun administering early third dose vaccinations for the elderly population, ahead of the original February national timeline.  On January 13, the government also announces the shortening of interval for 3rd doses in the general population to 7 months. Previously for the general public, this period was 8 months. For medical personnel and the elderly population, the interval was previously shortened to 6 months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117181752/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429491000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117182101/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429151000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117182045/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220111/k10013424521000.html

From FB Page of Radio Kiribati (not currently possible to archive link on archive.fo).  Unarchived link at bottom of summary.    *Schools are not referred to in this post.  It does refer to "All arms of government {government agencies) including private businesses will maintain their operations as usual ", suggesting that schools will remain open.    On Friday last week (14th January 2022), 54 passengers arrived on flight from Fiji and had 3 negative test results for Covid-19 prior to departure.  Of these, 36 were subsequently tested (presumably on arrival in Kiribati) with a postive Covid-19 result.  All passengers were according to the report "fully vaccinated", healthy and were in quarantine at Otintaai Hotel.    In addition, one of the 39 frontline staff tested positively for Covid-19.  This person, two colleagues and their families have been "taken into quarantine".    Kiribati is now on Alert Level 2 from 18th January-1st February.  A range of measures are set out:  a) Curfew 10pm-6am  b) Health measures: social distancing, hand washing, wearing masks (apart from at home)  c) Kava and liquor bars closed  d) Gatherings limited to up to 10 people  e) Public transport including ferries will continue to operate    https://www.facebook.com/rknews21/posts/302606985171380?__cft__[0]=AZV3PBsr7Udl4Qwwg7U0GQosJ3lNDt0lXNNlIESVQRyTLVPC8wQFfPAIAIszYZ_VVlhOSvys-85l8y4EOUBeUZGdmWZi9HiMwXDtY90QHR4Kc56pXMl3bMx4QuDDtUq7-oJAihY80KxgyJxyzaeupIScN4f1ZWLfeFgP-FXkbyeWsg&__tn__=%2CO%2CP-R

Announcement from Office of Te Beretitenti (President).  Not possible to archive link on archive.fo, so full link is given after summary.  The article is dated 24th January 2022, but refers to policy changes from 22nd January 2022 that affect South Tarawa, Betio and Buota.    Due to community transmission of Covid-19, from 22nd January 2022 at 3pm, South Tarawa and Betio were moved to Alert Level 3.  Measures include:  a) 24 hour curfew  b) "All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm."  c) " All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services "  d) "People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services."  e) "Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm."  f) "Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown."  g) "All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed."  h) "All kinds of social gatherings are banned."  i) "Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements."  j) "No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    https://www.president.gov.ki/news/91-ana-kaongora-ni-kamataata-h-e-beretitenti-taneti-maamau-iaon-te-covid-19-n-rekereke-ma-alert-level-3.html

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    "The Government has decided to extend the lockdown period on South Tarawa, Betio and Buota for 7 more days effective from 6am Friday 28 January 2022 to 6am Friday 4 February 2022. Furthermore, Te Beretitenti has also signed the extension of the Proclamation of a State Disaster to prepare for and manage the impact of novel corona virus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic for another 30 days effective from Saturday 29 January 2022 to 28 February 2022, following the first proclamation made on 22 January 2022. "    "Noting that South Tarawa, Betio and Buota are still on alert level three, the following measures are still in effect:  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  1. Lock-down with 24 hours curfew.   2. All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

Announcement from Office of Te Beretitenti (President).  Not possible to archive link on archive.fo, so full link is given after summary.  The article is dated 24th January 2022, but refers to policy changes from 22nd January 2022 that affect South Tarawa, Betio and Buota.    Due to community transmission of Covid-19, from 22nd January 2022 at 3pm, South Tarawa and Betio were moved to Alert Level 3.  Measures include:  a) 24 hour curfew  b) "All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm."  c) " All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services "  d) "People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services."  e) "Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm."  f) "Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown."  g) "All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed."  h) "All kinds of social gatherings are banned."  i) "Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements."  j) "No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    https://www.president.gov.ki/news/91-ana-kaongora-ni-kamataata-h-e-beretitenti-taneti-maamau-iaon-te-covid-19-n-rekereke-ma-alert-level-3.html

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    "The Government has decided to extend the lockdown period on South Tarawa, Betio and Buota for 7 more days effective from 6am Friday 28 January 2022 to 6am Friday 4 February 2022. Furthermore, Te Beretitenti has also signed the extension of the Proclamation of a State Disaster to prepare for and manage the impact of novel corona virus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic for another 30 days effective from Saturday 29 January 2022 to 28 February 2022, following the first proclamation made on 22 January 2022. "    "Noting that South Tarawa, Betio and Buota are still on alert level three, the following measures are still in effect:  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  1. Lock-down with 24 hours curfew.   2. All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

Announcement official Presidential Web Portal dated 12th January 2022    Confirms that Kiribati borders are now open and lists a range of measures - international arrivals only via South Tarawa, requires quarantine, does not exclude countries with active transmission of Covid-19 but does require more stringent conditions for arrivals from these countries.    "All incoming passengers will be required to provide proof of vaccination, COVID-19 test results, and will be quarantined upon arrival. Extra quarantine days for travellers from high-risk countries will be imposed in line with updated travel SOPs to safeguard Kiribati from COVID-19."    "The Taskforce confirmed that travellers from countries with active community transmissions of COVID-19 like Fiji and Australia, are required to be quarantined ten days before their departure and to be tested 48 hours before their flights. Upon arrival, these passengers will be tested again and quarantined for 14 days. Passengers who tested positive for COVID-19 will not be allowed to board inbound flights."    http://archive.today/2022.01.17-170807/https://www.president.gov.ki/news/88-kiribati-border-is-now-open-under-the-new-normal-conditions.html

The article is dated 24th January 2022, but refers to policy changes from 22nd January 2022 that affect South Tarawa, Betio and Buota.    *The measures outlined below do not refer to closing borders    Due to community transmission of Covid-19, from 22nd January 2022 at 3pm, South Tarawa and Betio were moved to Alert Level 3.  Measures include:  a) 24 hour curfew  b) "All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm."  c) " All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services "  d) "People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services."  e) "Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm."  f) "Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown."  g) "All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed."  h) "All kinds of social gatherings are banned."  i) "Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements."  j) "No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    https://www.president.gov.ki/news/91-ana-kaongora-ni-kamataata-h-e-beretitenti-taneti-maamau-iaon-te-covid-19-n-rekereke-ma-alert-level-3.html

There have been no references to re-instituting the border closure in recent responses to Covid-19 cases and the Office of the President website continues to refer to the borders being open from 10th January 2022.  (The border had been closed from March 2020-10th January 2022)

No specific reference is made in the guidelines to the international border which was opened on 10th January 2022.  Given that the guidelines indicate that no passengers are allowed on vessels or air services to the outer islands, it is likely that the international border is also effectively closed to international passengers.  Nevertheless the Office of Te Beretitenti website continues to refer to the planned border opening of 10th January and has not been changed since the emergency orders have been introduced.    "Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    http://archive.today/a205w

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    Covid variant found in community is confirmed to be Omicron.  "While it is also expected that there will be a rapid increase of infected people in the coming days and weeks, there is optimism that the impact on the public will not be as severe as it would have been if it were other variants of COVID-19 that we are dealing with. Schools reopened on 25 October 2021. Schools must follow epidemic prevention guidelines issued by DSEDJ and the Health Department, with social distancing (1 metre), wearing masks and limiting visitors to school facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211215145030/https://portal.dsedj.gov.mo/webdsejspace/internet/Inter_main_page.jsp?id=85469&langsel=E    Moreover, from February 21, 2022, all faculty members, college students, school teachers and staff must present proof of completing 2 doses of the primary series of COVID-19 vaccine 14 days ago, when entering the campus. Those who were not fully vaccinated 14 days ago (receiving 2 doses of mRNA vaccines or Inactivated vaccines in the primary series) need to take nucleic acid test every 7 days.    https://archive.vn/HP9wn

Is a curfew in place? No   Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No   Social distancing requirements: The Macau government requires the use of the Macau Health Code for entrance to certain locations like immigration buildings, medical institutions, casinos, hotels, a nd guesthouses. Similarly, temperature checks are mandatory in many settings. For more details, please see the Macau governmentâs COVID-19 website. As part of the Government of Macauâs declarations of a state of immediate pandemic prevention in September and October 2021, many regular services in Macau were suspended. As of late October 2021, recreational facilities have reopened. Ferry service between Macau and mainland China has resumed.  Education institutions resumed in-person classes on October 25, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220122051402/https://hk.usconsulate.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Myanmar reopened all basic education schools on Monday, including private schools and Buddhist monastic schools, with a decrease in daily Covid-19 infections in the country.    According to an announcement of Central Committee on Prevention, Control and Treatment for Covid-19, schools in 46 townships of nine regions and states will be excluded from reopening based on the analysis on the test positivity rates per 100,000 people in the past 14 days.    Since the COVID-19 infection has been under control in Myanmar, the universities, degree colleges and colleges under the Higher Education Department of the Ministry of Education opened on Thursday.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220111055355/https:/www.myanmaritv.com/news/university-education-fourth-year-and-post-graduate-courses-opened  https://web.archive.org/web/20220111060346/https:/www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/11/01/myanmar-reopens-schools-amid-drop-in-new-covid-19-cases
