The country is currently in Phase 3:  - All educational institutions are closed  - All learning activities are to be conducted virtually    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Private sector: Operational capacity limited to 80% at any one time, for business sectors allowed to operate  - Agricultural and commodities sector may operate at full capacity  *Only fully vaccinated workers are allowed to operate in premises    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Live performances and events are allowed without an audience    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html
The country is currently in Phase 3:  - All social activities and visitations are not allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks must be worn on public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129101556/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Number of people in a car is determined by the car's capacity    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Travelling between districts of the same state are allowed    Fully Vaccinated Individuals:  - Travelling to districts / states / country and tourism bubble areas is allowed  - Vehicles may carry passengers at full capacity    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

All travelers must undergo COVID-19 testing and most must quarantine at a facility designated by the Malaysian government.  The full cost of testing and quarantine must be borne by the traveler.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129101556/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

PSU 4.0 will be implemented over four months from Aug 1, 2021. A total allocation of RM3.8 billion (896.6 million USD) would be channelled to qualified employers and limited to 500 workers for each company.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111920/https://www.mof.gov.my/portal/en/news/press-citations/govt-allocates-rm3-8-bln-for-4-month-psu-4-0-from-aug-1-tengku-zafrul

Bank Negara Malaysia (Central Bank of Malaysia) provides loan repayment assistance:  Moratorium for 6 months.  No supporting documentation required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111954/https://www.bnm.gov.my/RA
The government has a dedicated website for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102417/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

Self-administered Testing kits are now also available to be ordered from the government website and have been since 21st June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018160735/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/garis-panduan/gp-umum-covid19/kit-ujian-kendiri-covid19-self-test-kit?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

The use of the MySejethera app is not mandated but generally used across Malaysia for many functions including booking vaccinations and tracking social movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226113805/https://mysejahtera.malaysia.gov.my/intro_en/
Facial coverings are required in Malaysia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102803/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malaysia/coronavirus

Vaccinations are freely available and fully funded by the government for all citizens and even foreign residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211225105249/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-malaysia-vaccines-idUSKBN2AB0E1

The country is currently in Phase 3:  "3 people in a household may go out (non-fully vaccinated)" in phase 3 regions, but did not specify elderly or not.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

PHASE 3(May 2021 â February 2022)  Adult population aged 18 years and above (citizens & noncitizens)  Priority will be given to those in the red zones; followed by those  in yellow zones and finally those in green zones  Registration for the vaccine, which will start on the 1st of March 2021, will be implemented  through the website www.vaksincovid.gov.my    https://web.archive.org/web/20211012103539/https://www.vaksincovid.gov.my/pdf/National_COVID-19_Immunisation_Programme.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211225104348/https://www.vaksincovid.gov.my/en/guide/?myshj

The government is targeting at least 60% of teenagers to receive at least one vaccination dose by November, with the aim of having 80% of teenagers fully vaccinated by next January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210930161720/https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2021/09/23/covid-19-over-half-a-million-adolescents-received-at-least-one-vaccine-dose-says-khairy
Both citizens and foreigners receive free vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424042948/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-malaysia-vaccines-idUSKBN2AB0E1
No policy change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211227095355/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/education-at-red/

New Zealand moves to Red at 11:59pm on 23 January, after 9 cases in the Nelson/Marlborough region were confirmed as the Omicron variant.    Tertiary students with a My Vaccine Pass will be able to attend classes, lectures, labs, workshops, tutorials and meetings in person. They can access research spaces, student support and advisory services.    Capacity is based on 1-metre distancing. Updates on the New Zealand government website on the 17th of January 2021 indicate as follows:  "Travel in Red areas:   You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at any traffic light setting. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.  You can travel for any reason.   Some transport providers, such as Air New Zealand, KiwiRail and Cook Strait ferry operators, may require you to show a My Vaccine Pass or negative COVID-19 test result before boarding if you are aged 12 years and 3 months or above. The test must be taken no more than 72 hours before your journey."    archived link -   https://archive.ph/FAw2K

Between 15 December 2021 and 17 January 2022, you can travel into and out of Auckland for any reason but you must follow some restrictions to leave Auckland.    When leaving Auckland, no matter how long you have been inside the boundary:    you must have your My Vaccine Pass with you, or  you must carry evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before crossing the boundary.    You will need to show your My Vaccine Pass or a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before crossing the boundary to enter Northland. As this is an LFT requirement not PCR, coded as a 1 after targeted restrictions focused on Auckland end    http://web.archive.org/web/20220108145518mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/

From January 17, 2022, COVID-19 immunisation starts for 5 to 11-year-old tamariki, the specific vaccine being administered is Pfizer.    Everyone in New Zealand aged 5 or over can get a free COVID-19 vaccine. It does not matter what your visa or citizenship status is.    Pfizer is the preferred COVID-19 vaccine for use in New Zealand.  If you are 18 years of age or older and either you cannot get the Pfizer vaccine or you want a different option, you can get the AstraZeneca vaccine.  https://archive.fo/qjXZ6    https://archive.fo/iV2vX

All financial institutions agreed to provide relief of 3 months on loan repayments and interest payments to customers who have lost their jobs, on a case-by-case basis. Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain government-paid or government-subsidized testing services at the National Referral Hospital in Honiara. Symptomatic persons should contact the Public Health Emergency Surveillance Unit at +677 23650 or +677 752 2202 for further instructions.    Non-symptomatic persons and persons who need testing services in connection with travel may obtain such services at the Ministry of Healthâs field hospital in Chinatown. Procedures for obtaining a test often change frequently; contact the Consular Agency in Honiara for the latest information: +677-23426.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116194453/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:    No Coding changes to the period of 14-18 Dec.  School holidays remain and school resumes in early January 2022. _______________     ***Please refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:  No further changes to schools opening [Link (1,2)]. Year-end School holidays to begin this Sat 20 Nov 2021, schools will reopen in 2022 [Link(3)]. From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.  A grace period for partially vaccinated individuals is in place until 31 January 2022.    50% of employees are now allowed back to the workplaces at any given point in time; although, they must adhere to the vaccine mandate as afore mentioned.  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings  ___________    Quote (2):  "The following measures are put in place to slow the rate of transmission and minimise strain on our healthcare capacity.  From 1 January 2022, more employees3 are allowed to return to the workplace.  Up to 50% of employees who are able to work from home can be at the workplace at any point in time. For example, a company with 100 employees who can work from home can have up to 50 of these employees at the workplace at any point in time."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220103082447/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/requirements-for-safe-management-measures

No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No Coding changes to the period of 14-18 Dec.   _______________  ***Please refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021 [Link (1)]. However, there are ongoing trials of limited relaxing of certain Covid safety measurements for selected events - working towards opening further for more events in the near future [Link (2)].    ___________________  Quote (1):  "LIVE PERFORMANCES, MICE, SPECTATOR & PARTICIPATORY SPORTS EVENTS  All vaccinated^ : 1,000 attendees  Unvaccinated: 50 attendees without PET  Group size limited to 2 persons^^.  Unmasking and singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances for vaccinated performers allowed."    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20211119090108/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory  ___________________    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE- People attending Mandopop star JJ Lin's charity concert later this month will not need to be seated one metre apart, as part of a new protocol that will relax some safe management measures at selected events.    Other measures that will be eased as part of the Government's plan to live with Covid-19 include doing away with zones or increasing zone capacity for event participants.    The new protocol, known as the vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) + Test, was announced by the authorities on Monday (Nov 15), as part of a plan to trial greater allowances at activities for those who are fully vaccinated."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20211118085034/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/consumer/jj-lin-concert-among-events-with-relaxed-covid-19-measures-such-as-no-1m-space

Vaccine differentiated measures are currently in place with only vaccinated individuals allowed into events. Current Covid safety measurements still prevail in all settings.  _________________    Quote (1):  " From 1 January 2022, the concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed. Only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented."    "ATTRACTIONS,SHOWS & CRUISES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated.    CONGREGATIONAL & WORSHIP SERVICES  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 worshippers.  Vaccinated performers or speakers may be unmasked, including for singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances.    MARRIAGE SOLEMNISATIONS  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 attendees.    MUSEUMS & PUBLIC LIBRARIES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128150314/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory  __________________    Quote (2):  "(D) Expanding VDS to More Venues    10. Vaccination is key to protecting our population even as SMMs are further relaxed. From 1 December 2021, we will expand VDS to more settings and activities, including in all Libraries under the National Library Board (NLB), and selected activities in community clubs/centres under Peopleâs Association (PA). By restricting entry to only individuals who have been fully vaccinated, we can further reduce the risk of transmission in such settings.     11. A summary of the updated community measures from 22 November 2021 can be found in Annex A.     (E) Removal of VDS Concession for Voluntarily Unvaccinated Individuals     12. We will further strengthen efforts to protect unvaccinated individuals from getting infected, as they are subject to greater risks of severe illness. Under current rules, unvaccinated individuals can get a PET and show a negative test result to enter a VDS setting. We will remove this concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated.  Hence, only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event-specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented. We will effect this on 1 January 2022, to allow time for more individuals to complete their primary series vaccination regime. "    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220116160914/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/resuming-our-transition-towards-covid-resilience

Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:    No Coding changes to the period of 14-18 Dec.   _________  ***Please refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021 [Link (1)].     _____________________________  Quote (1):  "How does COVID-19 spread?  Current evidence suggests that transmission of COVID-19 occurs primarily through the respiratory droplets of infected people, which are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks or sings. These respiratory droplets can reach the eyes, nose or mouth of a susceptible person directly or indirectly (via contaminated surfaces), resulting in infection.    Airborne transmission of the virus can occur in health care settings where aerosol-generating procedures are performed. While there have been limited reports of airborne transmission outside of health care settings internationally, its role and extent are under further study. MOH will continue to monitor the evidence as it emerges.    To reduce the risk of spread, members of public must wear a mask outside the home and observe safe distancing. Individuals should also observe good hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces if possible."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211119095432/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general

Vaccine differentiated measures for travelers to Singapore have been in place for many months and have recently increased to include a mandate for work passes. There are a few exceptions but these might require pre-approval but a government body.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "Persons who are medically unfit to be vaccinated are not allowed to travel under the VTL (Air).  Unvaccinated short-term visitors will not be allowed to travel to Singapore.    However, unvaccinated:  Singapore Citizens  Permanent Residents, and  Long-Term Pass holders who have received entry approval via the SC/PR Familial Ties Lane  may still travel to Singapore on a non-designated flight. They will be subject to the prevailing Stay-Home Notice (SHN) and COVID-19 test requirements upon entry into Singapore.    3. What must travellers present as their proof of vaccination at check-in and arrival immigration?  I am a...	My proof of vaccination was issued...	I will need to present...  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	In Singapore	Either a valid vaccination status on the TraceTogether or HealthHub app or a vaccination certificate issued by the Singapore Ministry of Health.  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	Overseas	One of the accepted proof of vaccination, which may include your overseas-issued vaccination certificate  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	In Singapore	A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*. Please click here for more details.  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	Overseas	  A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*, and an accepted proof of vaccination, if necessary.    *On the VTP (Air) application portal, please select one of the following options depending on your pass type:  MOM Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a holder of an Employment Pass, Work Pass, Dependentâs Pass, MOM Long-Term Visit Pass, etc.; or  MOE Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a Student Pass holder."    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152708/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/vtl/faq  _____________________    Quote (2):  "Covid Vaccination Mandatory In Singapore From February 2022  Singapore: Singapore has made Covid vaccination a mandatory condition for the approval of new applications for work passes, long-term passes and permanent residence in Singapore from February 1 next year. Those renewing their work passes will also have to be vaccinated, The Straits Times reported, citing the multi-ministry task force (MMTF) on Covid."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128152404/https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/coronavirus-covid-vaccination-mandatory-in-singapore-from-february-2022-2673179  ____________________    Quote (3):  "Calibrating Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) Testing Regimes    24.    On 31 December 2021, we announced a four-week extension to the enhanced 7- day testing regime for travellers arriving via VTLs in order to facilitate the detection of imported Omicron cases and slow transmission into the community. This has bought time for us to booster vaccinate more residents, learn more about the Omicron variant and make necessary adjustments to our COVID-19 strategy. As imported cases now form a shrinking proportion of our overall cases, we will simplify the VTL testing regime.    25.     These measures are less relevant now. Hence, VTL travellers entering Singapore after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours via both air and land checkpoints will only be required to do unsupervised self-administered ARTs from Day 2 to Day 7 of their arrivals if they need to leave their place of residence or accommodation. Travellers need not submit their ART results but must test negative before going out. VTL travellers who arrive before 23 January 2022, 2359 hours are still required to continue with the existing testing regime (i.e. unsupervised self-administered ART on Days 2, 4, 5 and 6 with submission of results online, and supervised ART on Days 3 and 7 from their arrival).    26.    Travellers who test positive on ARTs (i.e. the on-arrival test for VTL-Land and unsupervised self-administered ARTs on Days 2 to 7) no longer need to undergo a confirmatory PCR test, but should instead simply recover under Protocol 2.2 That said, those who identify themselves as potentially at risk (as stipulated in Annex C) should visit a doctor for medical advice after testing positive even if they feel well.    27.     We will continue to maintain a 50% limit on VTL flight and bus tickets for entry into Singapore for now. We will continue to review the local and global COVID-19 situation and adjust our measures accordingly.    Facilitating Travel for Recently-Recovered Travellers    28.    With the growing number of cases worldwide, there is a rise in the number of travellers who have recently recovered from COVID-19. Such travellers can continue to shed non-infectious viral fragments even after they have recovered, and therefore test positive for COVID-19 despite posing no infection risk. As fully vaccinated individuals who recently recovered from infection have a high level of immunity through their recent COVID-19 infection and vaccination, the likelihood of reinfection is low.    29.     Hence, travellers arriving after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours who are fully vaccinated and recently recovered (i.e. within 90 days of their last infection) will be exempted from all testing and SHN requirements if they are able to provide appropriate documentary proof. Non-fully vaccinated recently-recovered travellers will be exempted from pre-departure testing requirements, but will still be subjected to all other prevailing border measures. This will facilitate the safe return of recently-recovered residents who travel overseas. See Annex D for the list of documentation to be presented by such travellers at check-in and arrival immigration to qualify for this exemption."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152933/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/focusing-our-resources-and-refining-our-healthcare-protocols-to-deal-with-the-omicron-wave

In additon, the government announced SGD$130 million (Approx USD$ 95 million) stimuli in the form of cash vouchers that can be utilized at select merchants across the country,    ___________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - All Singaporean households can now collect $100 worth of vouchers that they can spend at about 10,000 participating hawkers and heartland merchants.    The community development council (CDC) vouchers, worth $130 million in total and given out to 1.3 million households, are available for collection digitally from Monday (Dec 13) and can be used till Dec 31, 2022."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213094222/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/100-worth-of-cdc-vouchers-for-each-sporean-household-available-for-collection-online  ________________    Quote (2): [Exchange Rate]  "Dec 13, 2021 09:38 UTC  Singapore Dollar	130,000,000.00 SGD	  US Dollar	95035922.924214	@ 1.367904"    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20211213094242/https://www.x-rates.com/historical/?from=SGD&amount=130000000&date=2021-12-13  ______________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021.     ____________________________________  ****Please refer to previous notes dated 6 Nov 2021:    no coding changes to the period of 02-06 Nov 2021.   ___________________  ***Please refer to notes dates 01 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 24 Oct -01 Nov.  ___________________  *** Please refer to notes dates 23 Oct 2021    Support to continue until Nov 21 in light of the further extensions of the current restrictions.  ___________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: A S$640 million support package will be rolled out for affected businesses and workers, after it was announced on Wednesday (Oct 20) that Singapore will extend its COVID-19 restrictions by nearly a month.  The stabilisation phase, which started on Sep 27 to help reduce the strain on the healthcare system, was scheduled to last until Oct 24.   It has now been extended until Nov 21, with a review of the measures at the two-week mark. They may be adjusted based on the situation then, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a media release.  During the stabilisation phase, social gatherings and dining-in have been capped at groups of two, while work-from-home has been the default arrangement.  Given the extended restrictions, the Government will continue with the Jobs Support Scheme until Nov 21, at 25 per cent wage support for sectors significantly affected by the tightened measures.  These include F&B, retail, cinemas, museums and art galleries, family entertainment, tourism, gyms and fitness studios, as well as performing arts and arts education.  A two-week rental waiver will be given to qualifying tenants on government-owned commercial properties.  Eligible tenant-occupiers and owner-occupiers of privately-owned commercial properties will also be given a 0.5-month rental relief cash payout under the Rental Support Scheme (RSS).  Cooked food and market stallholders in centres managed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) or operators appointed by NEA will receive a 0.5-month rental waiver.    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211023041636/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-support-package-jobs-support-scheme-extended-restrictions-2257036

The stabilisation phase, which started on Sep 27 to help reduce the strain on the healthcare system, was scheduled to last until Oct 24.   It has now been extended until Nov 21, with a review of the measures at the two-week mark. They may be adjusted based on the situation then, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a media release.  During the stabilisation phase, social gatherings and dining-in have been capped at groups of two, while work-from-home has been the default arrangement.  Given the extended restrictions, the Government will continue with the Jobs Support Scheme until Nov 21, at 25 per cent wage support for sectors significantly affected by the tightened measures.  These include F&B, retail, cinemas, museums and art galleries, family entertainment, tourism, gyms and fitness studios, as well as performing arts and arts education.  A two-week rental waiver will be given to qualifying tenants on government-owned commercial properties.  Eligible tenant-occupiers and owner-occupiers of privately-owned commercial properties will also be given a 0.5-month rental relief cash payout under the Rental Support Scheme (RSS).  Cooked food and market stallholders in centres managed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) or operators appointed by NEA will receive a 0.5-month rental waiver. Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211023041636/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-support-package-jobs-support-scheme-extended-restrictions-2257036  ____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dates 18 Oct 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 09-18 Oct 2021.  ___________________________  **** Please refer to notes dated 08 Oct 2021:    no coding changes for the period of 06-08 Oct 2021.  _______________________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 05 Oct 2021:    No coding changes to the period of 26 Sep to 05 Oct 2021.  ____________________    ***Please refer to notes dated 25 Sep 2021:  No coding changes to the period of 20-25 Sep 2021.   ____________  Quote (1):  "COVID-19 Recovery Grant - Temporary  The COVID-19 Recovery Grant â Temporary (CRG-T) provides temporary financial support for lower- and middle-income workers who have been placed on involuntary no-pay leave (NPL), or face income loss of at least 50% for one month, as a result of the tightened safe management measures (SMMs) during this period of Heightened Alert."    "COVID-19 Recovery Grant  The COVID-19 Recovery Grant (CRG) will help those with:    Loss of job (i.e. retrenchment, termination of employment contract)  Eligible to receive support of up to $700/month for 3 months   Involuntary No-Pay Leave (NPL) for at least 3 consecutive months  Loss of at least 50% salary on average for at least 3 consecutive months  Eligible to receive support of up to $500/month for 3 months  Loss of at least 50% Net Trade Income (NTI) on average for Self-Employed Persons (SEPs) for at least 3 consecutive months'    "The Courage Fund For Lower-Income Households affected by COVID-19  Target beneficiaries and eligibility criteria  The Courage Fund will help lower-income households affected by COVID-19 who meet the following criteria:  At least one household member is a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.  At least one household member contracted COVID-19, or was placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN), mandatory Leave of Absence (LOA) or Home Quarantine Order (QO).  [As of 1 Aug 2021] Household has current gross monthly income of =$6,200, or current gross monthly per capita income of =$2,000.  Household experienced a complete or partial (of at least 10%) loss of household income as a result of (2).  Households who have been affected by QO/SHN/LOA or from contracting COVID-19 more than once and continue to face protracted job or income loss can apply and receive up to two tranches of support, if they meet the other eligibility criteria.    Note: ComCare clients can apply.    Assistance provided  For each tranche, a one-time lump sum of up to $1,000 (depending on the household's per capita income after being affected by COVID-19), credited into bank account.  Please allow 2 - 3 weeks processing time for fund disbursement, upon submission of supporting documents."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20210925062514/https://www.msf.gov.sg/assistance/Pages/covid19relief.aspx  ________________________  Point (2):  Various schemes are available with the government setting up an online site to help individuals navigate the right places to get support.    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20210925062832/https://supportgowhere.life.gov.sg/  _______________________    Quote (3):  "Suspension of Repayment and Interest Accrual of Government loans:   Suspension of repayment and interest accrual of Tuition Fee Loan (TFL), Study Loan (SL), and Overseas Student Programme Loan (OSPL) for all Autonomous University and polytechnic graduates  ? There is no need to apply. All individuals with outstanding TFL, SL and OSPL will be automatically granted the suspension until 30 September 2021. "    "Loan Support:  - Temporary Bridging Loan Programme: Enhanced support for enterprisesâ working capital needs, to ease enterprisesâ access to credit and ready them for the new normal   - Enterprise Financing Scheme (Trade Loan):  Enhanced support for enterprisesâ trade financing needs, to ease enterprisesâ access to credit and ready them for the new normal  - Enterprise Financing Scheme â Venture Debt: Finance the growth of innovative enterprises using Venture Debt and Warrants"    Link (3): http://archive.today/2021.09.25-063116/https://www.mof.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider3/budget2021/download/pdf/fy2021_budget_navigator.pdf    ___________________________________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 10 Sep 2021:    No coding changes to the period of 07-10 Sep 2021.  __________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 06 Sep 2021:    Please refer to notes dated 14th June 2021:  No coding changes to the period of 06-14 June 2021.  ________________________________________  Quote (1):  "S$1.3 billion worth of GST voucher payments will be disbursed from June, benefiting about 1.4 million Singaporeans and 950,000 households, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Tuesday (Jun 1). The vouchers combine regular payments as well as one-off payments that are part of the S$900 million Household Support Package introduced to help families during this period of uncertainty amid COVID-19. Lower- to middle-income families are set to receive more support from the package, which was announced at Budget 2021 in February.FOR     INDIVIDUAL CITIZENS  About 1.4 million citizens will receive up to S$500 in GST vouchers this year. This comprises a one-off GST Voucher - Cash Special Payment of S$200 and a regular GST Voucher - Cash payment of up to S$300. The one-off payment and regular payment will be credited directly to citizens' bank accounts from Jun 23 and Jul 30 respectively, if they have linked their NRIC to their PayNow accounts.    FOR HOUSEHOLDS    About 950,000 Singaporean households living in public housing will receive their quarterly GST Voucher - U-Save rebates in July.  The households will also receive an additional 50 per cent rebate through a one-off GST Voucher - U-Save Special Payment.  In total, a household can expect to receive between S$355 and S$595 in rebates in financial year 2021, depending on the flat type.    Other government payments that eligible citizens can expect to receive later this year include the Five-Year MediSave Top-up scheme, grocery vouchers and top-ups to children's education accounts, said MOF. Households can also expect to receive rebates on service and conservancy charges and Community Development Council vouchers.     Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614134834/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/gst-voucher-u-save-cash-special-payment-mof-14924902      __________________  *** Please refer to notes dated 31 May 2021:  No coding changes for the period of 22-31 May 2021. However, new announcements have been made on the 28th of May to roll out further financial assisstance in light of the recent tightening of covid measures which saw many businesses like restaurants see an economic dive as footfall dwindles and diners barred from eating in. This in turn affected the wages of employees and their ability to make regular payments  such as monthly bills.  ___________________    Quote (1):  "3. Rental relief  Rental relief will be given to small and medium-sized enterprises and non-profit organisations with an annual revenue of not more than $100 million which are tenant-occupiers of some commercial properties. The Government will grant one month of rental relief for qualifying tenants in government-owned commercial properties. A similar one-month rental waiver had been announced earlier for hawker stalls and coffee shops. For privately owned commercial properties, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) will disburse a half-month rental relief cash payout to qualifying tenants as part of a new scheme, called the Rental Support Scheme."    "4. Suspension of repayment for tuition fee loans  The Ministry of Education (MOE) will extend the suspension of loan repayment and interest charges for another four months until Sept 30. This applies to tuition fee loans, study loans and overseas student programme loans for all autonomous university and polytechnic graduates. MOE had earlier suspended these charges for one year, from June 1 last year to May 31."    Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.05.31-155012/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/stepped-up-jobs-support-scheme-subsidies-temporary-relief-grant-for-workers-affected-by  _________________________    Quote (2):  "Rental relief will also be given to small and medium-sized enterprises as well as eligible non-profit organisations in commercial properties, while eligible lower- to middle-income workers and self-employed workers whose income have been affected by the measures can receive a one-off payout of up to $700 under a new Covid-19 Recovery Grant (Temporary)."    "Some support has been given to businesses and workers to cushion the impact of the measures, but companies have sought more help from landlords and the Government. For instance, food and beverage businesses will get 50 per cent wage subsidies under the JSS during the period for which dining in is prohibited, up from 10 per cent. Hawkers and coffee shop stallholders who are tenants of government agencies will also get a one-month rental waiver." No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No coding changes for the period of 14-18 Dec 2021. _  __________   ***Please refer to notes dated 13 Dec 2021:  Face masks continue to be mandated any time outside of the home. _    ______________    Quote (1): ""How does COVID-19 spread? Current evidence suggests that transmission of COVID-19 occurs primarily through the respiratory droplets of infected people, which are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks or sings. These respiratory droplets can reach the eyes, nose or mouth of a susceptible person directly or indirectly (via contaminated surfaces), resulting in infection.  Airborne transmission of the virus can occur in health care settings where aerosol-generating procedures are performed. While there have been limited reports of airborne transmission outside of health care settings internationally, its role and extent are under further study. MOH will continue to monitor the evidence as it emerges.  To reduce the risk of spread, members of public must wear a mask outside the home and observe safe distancing. Individuals should also observe good hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces if possible.""      Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20211206075819/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general

Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No coding changes for the period of 14-18 Dec 2021. _  __________   ***Please refer to notes dated 13 Dec 2021:  Face masks continue to be mandated any time outside of the home. _    ______________    Quote (1): ""How does COVID-19 spread? Current evidence suggests that transmission of COVID-19 occurs primarily through the respiratory droplets of infected people, which are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks or sings. These respiratory droplets can reach the eyes, nose or mouth of a susceptible person directly or indirectly (via contaminated surfaces), resulting in infection.  Airborne transmission of the virus can occur in health care settings where aerosol-generating procedures are performed. While there have been limited reports of airborne transmission outside of health care settings internationally, its role and extent are under further study. MOH will continue to monitor the evidence as it emerges.  To reduce the risk of spread, members of public must wear a mask outside the home and observe safe distancing. Individuals should also observe good hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces if possible.""      Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20211206075819/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general

Regardless of vaccination status, there are strict rules for each group of individuals before being able to enter nursing homes and hospitals to visit the elderly.    From the 24 of January, all in-persons will be suspended for 4 weeks until 20 February 2022 in light of the current omicron wave in Singapore.  _________________    Quote (1):  "[Updated 21 January 2022]    To better protect our patients and healthcare workers, particularly in settings with vulnerable persons, in-person visits to all hospital wards1 and residential care homes will be suspended for a period of four weeks, from 24 January to 20 February 2022 (both dates inclusive).    During this period, hospitals and homes can make assessments on a case-by-case basis to allow in-person visits for exceptional cases. More details for visits to hospitals and homes can be found below.    Pre-visit testing requirements at hospitals and homes    Visitors who are allowed into hospital wards and homes will be required to show a valid negative ART result obtained within the last 24 hours of each visit. All tests are to be self-funded by the visitor. This is a mandatory requirement for all visitors regardless of vaccination status, except for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 and are able to present a valid Pre-Event Test (PET) exemption notice2.   Fully vaccinated or medically ineligible visitors can perform an unsupervised self-administered ART or opt for an ART administered by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including tests performed at Quick Test Centres) to fulfil the pre-visit testing requirement. Those who opt to undergo unsupervised self-administered ART will be required to show evidence of a valid ART result, e.g. present a time-stamped photo of the dated ART result and photo ID for verification prior to entry.  Non-fully vaccinated visitors would be required to show results of ART administered or supervised by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including Quick Test Centres). Results from unsupervised self-administered ART will not be accepted for this group of visitors.    In-person visits at hospitals  The following patient groups will continue to be allowed visitors on a case-by case basis, as assessed by the hospitals:   a. Patients who are in critical condition;    b. Paediatric patients;   c. Birthing/post-partum mothers; and    d. Patients requiring additional care support from caregivers. Examples of caregivers include those providing assistance to inpatients who have mental incapacities or family members who are undergoing caregiver training to better  care for their loved ones after hospital discharge.      The above patient groups would be allowed only one pre-designated visitor, with one visit per day. Patients who are in critical condition may be allowed up to five pre-designated visitors, with a maximum of two visitors at the patientâs bedside at any one time.  All visitors approved to enter hospital wards must don face masks with good filtration capability at all times. These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric. Visitors are reminded not to eat or drink in the hospital wards or use the patientsâ toilets in the wards. They should also avoid sitting on patientsâ beds.    1Includes public acute hospitals, community hospitals and private hospitals   2 Recovered individuals (within last 180 days) can obtain a PET Exemption Notice from any clinic  offering ART or Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing services."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128155429/https://www.gov.sg/article/resuming-in-person-visits-to-hospitals-and-residential-care-homes  _______________    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - In-person visits to hospital wards and residential care homes will be suspended for the next four weeks amid a surge in Omicron Covid-19 cases over the past few weeks.  This is to protect Singapore's healthcare capacity and vulnerable seniors, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Friday (Jan 21). The suspension will last from next Monday (Jan 24) to Feb 20."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220122211503/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/visits-to-hospital-wards-nursing-homes-suspended-for-4-weeks-amid-covid-19-omicron-surge

The Minister for Education recommended 'school from home' until January 14th. However, some provinces e.g. Phuket have encouraged schools to return to on-site learning     https://archive.vn/l2YUt

21/1/22  Schools across Thailand are closed apart from those in Phuket. This order is valid until 31st January.    The Minister for Education recommended 'school from home' until January 14th. However, some provinces e.g. Phuket have encouraged schools to return to on-site learning     https://archive.vn/l2YUt

On 20th January 2022, the Ministry of Health issued guidance that it will not order schools to close unless clusters of Covid-19 cases turn up. Measures would also be targeted within the school; if cases are found, a particular classroom or grade might be ordered to close for cleaning for 3 days, rather than the entire school.      Additionally, the National News Bureau of Thailand reported on 18th January 2022 that many schools in Thailand have resumed onsite classes, but are also staggering the return of their students to reduce crowding. Some schools are for example, requiring some grades to remain fully online, while the rest of the students alternate the days that they attend in person, so that only 30% of the student body is present at any one time. Therefore, although many schools are open, significant public health precautions have been incorporated.     1.	The Nation | Thailand article: âNo school shutdowns unless clusters emergeâ: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124150009/https://www.nationthailand.com/in-focus/40011306  2.	National News Bureau of Thailand article: âSchools hold first on-site classes of 2022â: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124145222/https://thainews.prd.go.th/en/news/detail/TCATG220118165943585
No change from previous policy

According to a statement by the Thai Health Minister on 18th January 2022, the government has ordered entertainment venues catering to the nightlife to remain closed for the foreseeable future. While the government intends to relax restrictions in other economic sectors, it views these venues as being particularly high-risk for COVID-19 transmission.     Correlates with Tourism Authority of Thailand update on 23rd January 2022, stating that âall types of entertainment venues, including pubs, bars, and karaoke shops nationwide are to remain closed until further notice.â     It is noted that in practice, some of such venues have been able to re-open as ârestaurantsâ or âeateriesâ if they alter their services and meet certain government requirements. Other sources state that some entertainment venues that have not properly converted to restaurants have also re-opened illegally. Nonetheless coded as 2G to reflect official government policy, and because in practice, venues that do not have kitchen facilities are unable to legally convert to a restaurant.     1.	Tourism Authority of Thailand update: https://archive.vn/ft5i4  2.	ChannelNewsAsia article reporting on statement by Thai Health Minister: https://web.archive.org/web/20220123164614/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/thailand-lower-covid-19-alert-level-2442896   3.	Thai PBS News article: https://web.archive.org/web/20220123163956/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/bangkok-announces-continued-closure-of-entertainment-venues/   4.	Thaiger article: https://web.archive.org/web/20220123165750/https://thethaiger.com/news/bangkok/bma-follows-ccsa-bangkok-entertainment-venues-remain-closed   5.	MixMag Asia article: âJanuary 16th has come and gone but most clubs in Thailand remain in the dark.â https://archive.vn/WsDqz

From the 7th of January - "The Ministry of Public Health announced that it would elevate the COVID-19 alert to Level 4 to tackle the spread of the virus. They ask the public for cooperation to refrain from crowded places and social gathering activities"  https://archive.vn/FozMz

On 18th January 2022, the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration (BMA) announced that it will cancel the Chinese New Year celebrations that it normally organises at Bangkok's Yaowarat Road/Chinatown, due to concerns over the Omicron variant. However, apart from this specific government-organised event in Bangkok, have not found evidence of the BMA or other Thai authorities requiring other public events held by private actors to be cancelled.     The government offered safety tips for Chinese New Year, but there is no mention of a ban on public events. It is phrased as âadviceâ for people to generally avoid crowded places. Therefore, coded as 1G because there is a recommendation to avoid crowds, but without an actual requirement to cancel events.     Archived sources:   1. Thai Government Public Relations Department (official Facebook page) (English): https://archive.ph/OeRkH  2. Matichon Online Newspaper (Thai): https://archive.ph/aO9zp  3. The Nation | Thailand (English): "No Chinese New Year celebrations in Chinatown.": https://archive.ph/0a6Np   4. Thai PBS News (English): "Bangkok City Hall cancels Chinese New Year celebrations as Omicron spreads": https://archive.vn/BYsSo  5. Thai PBS News (English): "Safety tips from the Thai government for Chinese New Year celebrations." https://web.archive.org/web/20220122102014/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/safety-tips-from-the-thai-government-for-chinese-new-year-celebrations/
No change from prior policy

Thailand utilises a colour-coded zoning system for COVID-19 restrictions (From high restrictions to low: Dark Red, Red, Orange, Yellow, Blue). Presently, no provinces are classified dark red, red or yellow, but most provinces (69 out of 76) are classified in the orange zone for the period of 18thâ23rd January 2022. In orange zones, gatherings of no more than 500 people are permitted. Government announced on 20th January that it will relax restrictions and move 25 provinces from the orange to yellow zone, but this will only take effect on 24th January 2022.     Coded 2G; although some provinces are in the more relaxed blue zone (where restrictions have been eased with an eye on allowing the tourism sector to recover due to its importance to the Thai economy), the vast majority of provinces (69/76) have orange zone restrictions.     Archived sources:  1. Tourism Authority Thailand update stating that 69 provinces will be designated in the orange zone with effect from 9th January 2022: https://web.archive.org/web/20220122213830/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-steps-up-covid-19-curbs-nationwide-from-9-january-2022/  2. Bangkok Post article dated 21st January 2022, confirming that 69 provinces are presently in the orange zone, and that 25 provinces will be reclassified within the yellow zone from 24th January 2022: https://archive.vn/GIewc

Thailand uses a colour-coded zoning system for assigning COVID-19 restrictions to its 76 provinces and the Bangkok Special Administrative Area. These classifications, in the order of most restrictive to least restrictive are: dark red, red, orange, yellow and blue. Currently, no provinces are classified red or dark red. Restrictions on gatherings are as follow: orange â up to 500 people, yellow and blue â up to 1000 people.     With effect from 24th January 2022, the government has moved 25 provinces from the orange to yellow zone. 44 provinces remain classified in the orange zone, with the remainder in the blue zone. While it is important to note these zoning changes, the classification remains unchanged at 2G because gatherings are still restricted to no more than 1000 people nationwide.     Archived sources:  1.	Bangkok Post article, 21st January 2022: âCovid rules to ease as threat wanesâ: https://archive.vn/GIewc   2.	Garda Crisis24 Risk Management Report on Thailandâs most recent COVID-19 management measures: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124044026/https://crisis24.garda.com/insights-intelligence/intelligence/risk-alerts/wip10011892869/thailand-authorities-to-ease-covid-19-curbs-in-some-provinces-from-jan-24-resume-test-and-go-program-applications-from-feb-1-update-68

There have been no restrictions on closing public transport. However, there has been some misinformation regarding the closure of key transport links, which the Ministry of Transport have confirmed as false    https://archive.vn/xbLuE

Have not found indications of any restrictions on public transport being imposed in recent Thai government announcements otherwise giving updates on planned changes to Covid-19 measures. By contrast, previous closures were announced and widely reported upon. Furthermore, public transport providers, such as the Bangkok Metro, have indicated they are operating normally, emphasising that commuters should cooperate with public health measures and minimise the spread of Covid-19 by wearing masks.     As of 24th January 2022, the UK Foreign Officeâs travel advice for Thailand only warns of potential disruptions to public transport due to political rallies, rather than Covid-19 management measures.     Archived sources:  1.	Tourism Authority of Thailand update: https://archive.vn/ft5i4   2.	MRT Bangkok Metro, official Facebook account, post and infographic posted on 24th January 2022 (Thai). Approximate translation: âWe ask for the cooperation of all passengers. Please wear a mask while travelling, and do not pull your mask down underneath your chin.â https://archive.vn/wrqeG  3.	UK Foreign Office, Foreign travel advice, Thailand. Updated 24th January 2022: https://archive.vn/PTJrj
No change in prior policy

Thailand is presently at level 3, out of its 5-level alert system. At level 3, government advisories may recommend measures like working from home, but it is not mandated. There are also no curfews for Covid-19 management in effect. Many economic sectors and activities that are not considered essential services have been allowed to operate/take place. The Nation | Thailand: âDrinking time extended by two hours in âorangeâ and 'blue' provinces.â https://archive.vn/kW8dj

People who have travelled to 'high-risk provinces' are encouraged to remain vigilant     "The Department of Disease Control has stated that after the New Year holiday there is a rising of COVID-19 infections in many provinces of Thailand. They have advised the public who travel back from the high-risk provinces should observe their symptoms for 14 days, avoid gathering with others or visiting risked places, and keep following the hygiene practices. The ministry also asks those who recently travel to risk provinces and have to go to work at the office to test with ATK twice in the first week, the second test should apart from the first test at least 3 days. Those who have a positive test should isolate themselves and immediately go into the treatment process. For more information or advice about the COVID-19, please contact the DDC hotline at 1422."  https://archive.vn/6Vdtu

Thailand utilises a 5-level alert system. On 18th January 2022, the Thai government announced it would be lowering the alert level to 3, from 4. Under level 3, people are not prohibited from travelling internally, but are encouraged to minimise it. Those who travel between provinces must also be tested.    1.	Thai PBS News: Explanation of levels 1-5: https://archive.vn/GYqR7   2.	ChannelNewsAsia: âThailand to lower COVID-19 alert, ease curbs as infections slow.â âhttps://web.archive.org/web/20220123164614/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/thailand-lower-covid-19-alert-level-2442896

Unvaccinated passengers who are not part of the 'Sandbox Programme' must undergo a 10 day quarantine.  From January 11th, the travel ban on visitors from the following African countries : Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, and South Africa, has been lifted. The Test and Go scheme has continued to remain suspended  https://archive.vn/uDs8b

For the period of 18thâ24th January 2022, quarantines are compulsory for travellers to Thailand. There are however, differentiated rules based on vaccination status, with stricter rules for unvaccinated people (the "Alternative Quarantine" scheme). Unvaccinated travellers to Thailand must quarantine for 10 days and undergo 2 PCR tests upon arrival. Before travelling to Thailand, a negative PCR test taken no earlier than 72 hours prior to departure is also required, except for travellers under the age of 6. Travellers from any country in the world can enter via this scheme.     Additional notes: Vaccinated travellers can undergo a shorter 7-day quarantine, but must also take pre-departure and post-arrival PCR tests. The Thai government has announced that it will further relax international travel controls, but these will come into effect only on 1st February 2022.     Archived sources:  1.	Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook post (English):  https://archive.vn/2RqQd   2. Royal Thai Embassy, Beijing: "Entry requirements for entry to Thailand with effect from 11th January 2022" (English & Chinese): https://archive.vn/cZh8Y  4.	Royal Thai Embassy, Canberra: âSchemes for entering Thailandâ (English): https://archive.vn/nlmpY  5.	Tourism Authority of Thailand (English): https://archive.vn/i8WT6

17th January - the launch of a new income support scheme. "The government's "Khon La Khrueng" or 50:50 co-payment subsidy scheme will be launched mid-February, to mitigate the impact of Covid-19 and relieve people's living costs. Registration will begin on February 14 and spending by registrants can be made on February 21. The scheme will also cover users of the Pao Tang application, new registrants, state welfare cardholders and those in need of special assistance."

On 21st December 2021, the government additionally set up a relief scheme for workers in the nightlife sector, many of whom lost wages due to the continued, mandated closure of such entertainment venues, whereas other economic sectors were allowed to reopen to varying degrees. The Labour Ministry is presently disbursing a one-time payment of 5,000 baht. Freelance workers are also eligible for it, but must register with the social security scheme and also be certified by certain trade associations by 28th January 2022.     Archived source:  1.	Bangkok Post: âEntertainers register for govt aid planâ: https://archive.vn/u6KZa

On 24th January, the 4th phase of âKhon La Khreungâ, the Thai governmentâs co-payment subsidy scheme was approved. Through this scheme, the government co-pays 50% of certain living costs (food, drink and other goods and services), capped at a maximum of 150 baht/day. Phase 3 had expired on 31st December 2021, and Phase 4 will come into effect from 1st February 2022 to 30th April 2022. Coded as 1A because there are still other ongoing schemes to provide income support (such as to the nightlife workers, as mentioned in the 18th January 2022 note).     Archived sources:   1.	Bangkok Post: â4th phase of co-pay subsidy scheme approvedâ: https://archive.vn/BeffH   2.	Thai PBS World: âGovernment approves fourth phase of co-payment scheme, starting February 1.â https://web.archive.org/web/20220124170151/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/government-approves-fourth-phase-of-co-payment-scheme-starting-february-1/
No change in prior policy

The government has reiterated that addressing household debt is a priority in 2022, and that it intends to use various measures such as debt negotiation and restructuring. It intends to assist in relieving a wide range of debts, ranging from student loans to automobile and motorcycle debt.     Archived sources:  1.	Bangkok Post: https://archive.vn/XgitR    2.	National News Bureau of Thailand: https://archive.vn/sfpKj   3.	Bank of Thailand: https://archive.vn/7Pooq
No change in prior policy

Coordinated and detailed public information campaign on the Thai government's official websites, as well as accounts on social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter). Information campaign is in both Thai and English, on a variety of issues: providing nationwide COVID-19 statistics daily, advice about taking precautions when working-from-home, caring for vulnerable/elderly individuals and vaccination information. There are also Chinese language resources available on the governmentâs COVID-19 Information Center page. Many pages include links to regular press conferences given by Thai officials. As of this date, these pages have been updated regularly, often multiple times a day.     Archived sources:    1.	Thai Government Covid-19 Information Center page (Thai, English and Chinese): https://archive.vn/F11GO   2. No change in prior policy

Present testing policy: lateral flow/rapid antigen tests are available to be purchased at subsidised prices. The government has also distributed some tests for free. Anyone who tests positive on a rapid test is supposed to report it and obtain a PCR test (administered by a health worker) to confirm the result.     Free PCR tests are also being offered to Thai citizens and foreign travellers who require it under the Test & Go scheme, regardless of symptoms.     Additional notes: However, there have been difficulties caused by the shortage of rapid test kits, due to the spread of Omicron increasing demand. Such shortages could impact access to PCR tests, since a positive lateral test is the gateway to getting a PCR test.     Archived source:   1.	Thaiger: âThose who donât report positive ATK results can face penalties â DDC directorâ https://archive.vn/rh28U   2.	Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook post about appointments for free PCR tests under the Test & Go scheme: https://archive.vn/QAS0O   3.	Bangkok Post: âTest kit snags worsenâ. https://archive.vn/RL1O8
No change in prior policy

Classified as limited, rather than comprehensive contact tracing (which requires both declared intention to trace for all identified cases, and evidence of capacity to do so) for the following reasons:    A.	Evidence of high daily case numbers and widespread, ongoing community transmission nationwide, that might render comprehensive contact tracing both impossible and less useful as a disease control measure as opposed to in earlier stages of the pandemic.      Thailand has been recording around 7,000+ new infections/day (as confirmed by a PCR test) for the period of 18â24 Jan 2022.     1.	Thai Department of Disease Control, official Facebook, infographic for 24 Jan 2022: â7,139 new casesâ.     Thai language version: https://archive.vn/G41zn   English language version: https://archive.vn/2nsFe     2.	https://archive.vn/4eGFF â World Health Organisation Situation Report for Thailand for 13â19 Jan 2022: Average of â7,257 new casesâ per day and âcommunity transmission of Omicron in most provinces.â     B.	Recent government guidelines state that people who discover they have Covid-19 after testing with home ATKs (antigen test kits) must report their result to the authorities, get it confirmed with a PCR test and undergo isolation. However, those with mild or no symptoms are asked to self-isolate at home in order âto ease the burden on the public health care system.â     https://archive.vn/oxD9a â Thaiger: âThailandâs updated Covid guidelines: What to do if you test positive or have symptoms.â     C.	Government strategy seems to have also shifted to making home Covid-19 tests widely available for people so they can find out if they should take a PCR test and self-isolate, and utilising vaccinations. By comparison, there does not seem to be much mention of tracing the contacts of all known cases. Nonetheless, the possibility that some contact tracing may still be going on in targeted areas is not discounted.     https://archive.vn/rvnUw â Thai Government Public Relations Department, Twitter post on making antigen kits available at low cost in response to high demand.    https://archive.vn/VEGGV and  https://archive.vn/X2JMF â Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook posts encouraging vaccinations. Also emphasises masking, social distancing and good hygiene, but not so much contact tracing.    https://archive.vn/BG9q9 â Bangkok Post, 19th January 2022: ââ¦[A]ll agencies tasked with quelling the outbreak [in Bangkok] have been instructed to focus their efforts on dishing out booster shots, particularly to the elderly and those with pre-existing medical conditions.â    D.	Recent mentions of contact tracing usually refer to contact tracing apps. Thai authorities have encouraged everyone to download Mor Chana and Thai Chana, Thailandâs contact tracing apps. However, this by itself does not amount to manual, comprehensive contact tracing carried out by the authorities.     Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook post: https://archive.vn/7UAUg   Thai PBS News: https://archive.vn/6cBgO

No policy change. News articles detail enforcement responses by authorities over failure of tourists to wear masks in public, and complaints by parents referencing continued strict mask rules in schools for students. Thailand travel advice by foreign missions also continue to mention mask requirements and reference possible liability for fines. Additionally, on the Thai Governmentâs Public Relations Department official Facebook page; the banner states âSTOP COVIDâ¦keep wearing a mask at all times when in publicâ as of 24th January 2022.     The phrasing "advised" to "wear a mask in public" rather than "compulsory" has been used in some other government communications that were published in English, but have not found announcements actually announcing relaxation of mask rules that were instituted in 2021, so interpreted as no national policy change based on overall picture of sources.     1.	Thai Government Public Relations Department Facebook page showing banner: https://archive.vn/3kzCe   2.	Phuket News: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120183524/https://www.thephuketnews.com/patong-police-to-crack-down-on-face-masks-82803.php   3.	Thaiger: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120193907/https://thethaiger.com/news/national/parents-and-teachers-protest-against-atk-test-and-face-mask-mandates-at-schools   4.	UK Foreign Office, foreign travel advice for Thailand: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120195656/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus  5.	Australian government travel advice for Thailand: https://web.archive.org/web/20211111013415/https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/destinations/asia/thailand

The government announced on 24th January 2022 that it will start vaccinating children aged 5-11 for the first time, from 1st February 2022 onwards. Although this group is subsumed within the larger 5-15 years old age bracket for the purposes of the dataset, the vaccines had previously been available only for children aged 12 and above.     Children aged 5-11 are not prioritised vis a vis other age brackets, as sufficient vaccines for adults are available. However, the government has said that within the 5-11 age group, it will focus on first vaccinating children who have underlying health conditions such as asthma and obesity. An initial shipment of 3 million Pfizer vaccines that will be arriving in late January is part of a larger vaccine procurement of 10 million.    Archived sources:  1. Thai Government Public Relations Department, post on official Twitter account: https://archive.vn/wDOgb   2. Bangkok Post: "Pfizer jabs for 5-11s to arrive next week.": https://archive.ph/N4knC   3. Reuters: "Thai agency approves Pfizer vaccine for use in children aged 5-11": https://archive.vn/JRURK

Timor-Leste Travel update from UK government website:  -A State of Emergency is no longer in place in Timor-Leste. The latest one ended on 28 November 2021. Entry to national territory is no longer subject to authorisation from the Prime Minister, while entry to the country continues to be subject to medical screening. If a passenger is found infected with COVID-19, he or she will be taken to quarantine for further consultation and treatment. All passengers travelling to Timor-Leste should always present to the airport competent authorities the following: vaccination certificate and a negative COVID-19 PCR test result done within the last 72 hours before the time of departure. The test needs to be in one of these language: Indonesian, Portuguese or English. Failure to present the two documents, will be subjected to 14 days of quarantine.  -It is mandatory for all individuals to practice COVID-19 safety measures, including wearing a mask, washing hands frequently, and maintaining social distance of at least two metres.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110221559/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/timor-leste/coronavirus

Timor-Leste Government Website â media release:  *The Council of Ministers approved a Decree-Law draft presented by the Minister of Finance, Rui Augusto Gomes, which aims to create and regulate temporary and extraordinary financial support to be granted to employing companies and individual workers who do not work as employees and who are registered in the social security system. This diploma aims to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic, as well as to contribute to the maintenance of jobs and the survival of companies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110220619/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=29825&lang=en

Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021    FISCAL  The revised 2021 budget approved in late April includes an unprecedented fiscal response to deal with the recent COVID-19 outbreak. The COVID-19 Fund was increased to 17.7 percent of non-oil GDP. The funds will be used to purchase vaccines, protective equipment, and more material for testing and treatment. They will also finance employment support, internet connection for students, a supplement for front-line workers, and a basic consumption basket.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117233826/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T
No new update on this.

Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021    MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  The authorities introduced a credit moratorium for 3 months in August 2020 which led to 23 percent of total bank loans being restructured. This scheme has been reintroduced for 2021, with an extended duration of 9 months. Moreover, the credit guarantee scheme was extended to cover micro-enterprises in addition to small and medium enterprises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117233826/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T

Passengers arriving in Taiwan between 14 December 2021 and 14 February 2022, will be required to complete one of the following quarantine programmes:    Programme A  14 day mandatory quarantine at either a quarantine hotel or a designated quarantine facility.    Programme B  10 day mandatory quarantine at either a quarantine hotel or a designated quarantine facility, followed by a 4 day quarantine at your residential property. The total quarantine period is 14 days.    Programme C  This programme is only available for passengers who have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 for at least 2 weeks before arriving in Taiwan.    7 day mandatory quarantine at either a quarantine hotel or a designated quarantine facility, followed by a 7 day quarantine at your residential property. The total quarantine period is 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116054928/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/entry-requirements

Key measures of the covid relief package 4.0:  Accelerating relief for individuals: In addition to administering aid in accordance with last year's standards, a subsidy is available for families with students enrolled in elementary school and below, as well as disabled students in junior and senior high school and the first three years of five-year junior colleges. Living allowances are also going out to children, young people, the elderly and the disabled in low to middle-low income households. Excluding those above a certain income, agricultural and fisheries workers, the self-employed, and workers without fixed employers also receive living allowances.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055359/https://english.ey.gov.tw/News3/9E5540D592A5FECD/10e57174-8e16-4710-b4ac-9882bd8db7de
