A Level 2 alert means the following measures are now in place:  Contact tracing procedures must be completed when entering restaurants, shops, and some public places    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116054415/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

A Level 2 alert means the following measures are now in place:  Facemasks must be worn at all times when outdoors. Exceptions are permitted when consuming food and beverages and when in certain open spaces e.g. forests, mountains and beaches    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116054415/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

COVID-19 vaccine appointments for the first shot, second shot, or booster shot are widely available to people aged 12 or older.    Eligibility: individuals who registered on the System before 6 a.m. on December 13 and meet any of the following criteria:  1. The first dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 12 or older (born on December 16, 2009, or earlier).  2. The second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 31, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of BNT before November 18 (inclusive).  3. Mixing of AZ with a second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 16, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of AZ before October 21 (inclusive).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116062114/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kaT7wZ1ubFZzyHlWUQsENg?typeid=158

On January 9, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) announced that COVID-19 response measures for residential long-term care facilities in Taipei City, New Taipei City, Keelung City, Taoyuan City will be adjusted starting today in response to community infections associated with the Omicron cluster infection at Taoyuan International Airport. Key points of the changed measures are listed below.     Visitation management: visits will not be allowed except for certain situations. People who obtain the permission of the facilities for a visit under a special situation must present a negative result from a self-paid COVID-19 test taken within three days prior to their visit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116062801/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/Hjz8pXEpjEnqPGLP53Qs0Q?typeid=158

Vietnam has reduced quarantine requirements for fully vaccinated international arrivals from January 1, 2022. Arrivals with negative COVID-19 RT-PCR test results would only need to self-quarantine at home or their places of accommodation for three days when they enter Vietnam. Two RT-PCR tests will be conducted on the first and third day of entry. If negative, entrants are still required to monitor their health for the next 11 days. Further details are likely to be released by the health and transport ministries.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220124222012/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/covid-19-vietnam-travel-updates-restrictions.html/
no policy change

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Vietnam? [Yes]  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? [Yes]  Information about testing requirements for travel, the list of COVID-19 testing locations , and detailed instructions on how to register for testing, is available here.  This page also includes information about COVID-19 testing for both individuals departing Vietnam on international flights and for domestic travel within Vietnam, as well as the option of pre-boarding test at Noi Bai Airport (Hanoi) and Tan Son Nhat Airport (HCMC).  Beginning January 22, all airline passengers, including children under 12 years old, no longer need to present proof of full COVID-19 vaccination and negative testing prior to boarding.  Vietnam currently only requires airline passengers departing from areas identified by the Vietnamese government as âVery High Risk (Level 4)â to present a rapid SARS-CoV-2 antigen testing certificate issued within 72 hours prior to boarding.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125064023/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
no policy change

Social distancing rules remain in place in many places across Vietnam and you should follow these strictly. Mask wearing is compulsory in public settings. To date, nine vaccines in Emergency Use Authorization by NRA of Viet Nam: AstraZeneca, Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson  & Johnson (Janssen), Sinopharm BIBP, Sputnik V, and Hayat-Vax COVID-19 (Sinopharm manufacturing site), Abdala  and recently Covaxin (produced by Bharat Biotech International Limited, India)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220125072030/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/countries/viet-nam/covid-19/viet-nam-moh-who-covid-19-sitrep_2jan2022.pdf?sfvrsn=e43a1715_5

The priority groups:    Medical workers  Those who participate in COVID-19 prevention and control work (members of steering committees on COVID-19 prevention and control, staff working in quarantine camps, volunteers, reporters)  Military personnel  Police force  Vietnamese diplomats and their relatives; people working in diplomatic missions and international organizations in Viet Nam  Customs and immigration officers  Those working to maintain the supply of essential services such as aviation, transportation, tourism, electricity and water supply  Teachers, students, young doctors, people working in agencies and administrative units, law, notaries and auctioneers organizations who frequently contact with many people  People with chronic diseases, people aged 65 and over  Residents in pandemic-hit areas  Poor people and social policy beneficiaries  People who are sent by a competent authority to study or work abroad or others who wish to go abroad to study or work, and foreign experts working in Viet Nam  Factory workers and their relatives  Religious dignitaries  Freelance workers  Other subjects decided by the Minister of Health and Chairpersons of provincial/municipal People's Committees or proposed by vaccine donors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125071406/https://www.ccifv.org/en/vietnam/covid-19-information/covid-19-vaccination-in-vietnam.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220125072030/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/countries/viet-nam/covid-19/viet-nam-moh-who-covid-19-sitrep_2jan2022.pdf?sfvrsn=e43a1715_5
